image.altText: Wedge Fire, WA

props.synopsis: Residents of Cervantes are being told to evacuate immediately, with a massive fire that was first sparked by a car crash threatening the small fishing town.

title.children: Entire town told to evacuate in massive emergency bushfire north of Perth

image.altText: An Indigenous Australian man stands outside a building looking happy.

props.synopsis: Thousands of Aboriginal station workers who had their wages withheld or stolen due to discriminatory government policy will be compensated $16,500 each, the Federal Court rules.

title.children: Aboriginal station workers and their families to share $144 million in stolen wages class action

image.altText: Former MP Barry Urban walks out of Perth Magistrates Court looking to one side.

props.synopsis: Disgraced former Labor MP Barry Urban is fighting for his life in a Perth hospital after being attacked at work.Â

title.children: Disgraced former Labor MP Barry Urban fighting for life after attack at Perth tyre business

image.altText: A composite image of Libby Mettam and Basil Zempilas.

props.synopsis: Their election defeat in 2021 should have been rock bottom, but now an unsuccessful leadership push has left the WA Liberals bruised, fractured and disunited, just months before another poll.

title.children: Mettam, Zempilas tainted by leadership test that thrust WA Liberal dysfunction into the spotlight

image.altText: A close up of a woman in reflective sunglasses and rugged up in a sleeping bag, appears emotional, with clouds behind and below.

props.synopsis: Chris Kerr faced more challenges than most to get to the top of Africa's tallest peak, but she was adamant being a wheelchair user would not stop her.

title.children: Woman celebrates life-changing journey to summit of Mount Kilimanjaro in all-terrain wheelchair

image.altText: A wide v shaped line that looks bull dozed into a shrubby desert landscape from an aerial view.

props.synopsis: The origin of the strange clearing, which is still visible today, was detected by a scientist trawling through satellite data.

title.children: A tornado tore across the Nullarbor but we're only just learning about it now

image.altText: Tyler smiles while holding up a large nugget of gold.

props.synopsis: Tyler Mahoney likes to call herself a "professional gold digger" â but that doesn't mean what you think it means.Â

title.children: In a world where card payments rule, this 'gold digger' says cash is still king in the outback

image.altText: Tonia and her daughter are getting into a car with a backpack from Backpack Buddies.

props.synopsis: Researchers and frontline charities are seeing a growing number of Australian children going hungry and missing school, as the twin pressures of a cost-of-living crisis and housing shortages push families to the brink.

title.children: 'How are we surviving?â: Parents struggle to feed children, keep them in school amid cost-of-living crunch

image.altText: A close up of a stone cross on top of a church roof with grey background.

props.synopsis: Survivors of institutional child sexual abuse are left disappointed as the WA government rejects a host of recommendations from an inquiry aimed at improving support available to them, including allowing the names of known child abusers to be published prominently on church websites.

title.children: 'Itâs actually quite cruel': WA government slammed over response to child sex abuse inquiry

image.altText: A ranbow over a mural, two people playing on stage, about nine men and women stand in front, big speakers on side.

props.synopsis: WA has struggled to hold big commercial music festivals since the COVID pandemic. However, small-scale events targeting specific genres are proving more successful.

title.children: In a small town in WA's South West, two very different music festivals were held with great success

image.altText: Tanya Plibersek holds a python at Parliament House

props.synopsis: After an intense day on Tuesday of last-minute negotiations and lobbying by environmental and mining groups in which a deal was said to have "come close", the government has now shelved the talks.

title.children: Environmental protection laws appear doomed as deal with Greens fizzles amid fears of WA backlash

image.altText: Kids beneath a windmill at sunset.

props.synopsis: Carnarvon School of the Air students have shed light on what life is like in the outback in a special music video.

title.children: Outback kids juggle mustering and filming to put their lives on the land to music

image.altText: A white car with bumper  and side door crumpled rests against a pillar, glass and other debris.

props.synopsis: Australia is on track to record its deadliest year in more than a decade after the number of people who lost their lives on the nation's road passed 1,000.

title.children: More than 11,000 people have died on Australian roads in the past 10 years. There are fears things will get worse

image.altText: A man holds a video game console while smiling towards the camera.

props.synopsis: Joshua Wong was born with the rare Maffucci syndrome which meant most physical activity was out of the question, but video games allowed him to run and jump without limits.

title.children: How video games empower players with disability to find fun, friendship and community

props.synopsis: Your guide to finding the best stories from ABC News reporters in Perth and across WA.

title.children: Welcome to WA Top Stories, where local news lives

image.altText: An Indigenous woman and a toddler look at the camera for a photo.

props.synopsis: Prosecutors in Japan call for an Australian grandmother accused of importing 2 kilograms of methamphetamine to be jailed for 10 years as her trial draws to a close.

title.children: 'Why didn't she just tell the truth?' Japanese prosecutors want 10 years in jail for Perth gran, drug trial hears

image.altText: Smoke billows over a residential area and highway

props.synopsis: The 14-year-old boys accused of allegedly starting a bushfire that triggered the first emergency warning in Perth this bushfire season, forcing the closure of Tonkin Highway, had lost control of a campfire, a court hears.

title.children: Boys lost control of 'little campfire' that forced closure of major Perth highway, court hears

image.altText: Household money pic

props.synopsis: Australia's inflation rate remained steady in October, with rising prices for food, alcohol, cigarettes and recreational activities keeping it at 2.1 per cent annually.

title.children: RBA still unlikely to lower interest rates in 2024 despite inflation at its lowest level in more than three years

image.altText: A man stands at a lectern.

props.synopsis: The ABC's chair Kim Williams calls for more investment in the public broadcaster as a counter to the "flood" of online misinformation and disinformation, days after the federal government's decision to abandon legislation that would have forced social media giants to tackle harmful content on their platforms.

title.children: ABC chair warns Australia 'flooded' with misinformation days after government abandons bill to tackle social media content

image.altText: Road across Nullarbor Plain

props.synopsis: Plans lodged with WA's Environmental Protection Authority this month will bring wild transformation to an ancient desert landscape. Experts, who note the proposed scale is "incredible", say the idea has a lot going for it.

title.children: A mega energy project would bring 8,000 workers to the outback. What are the odds of it going ahead?

image.altText: a woman is sitting at a table looking at a utility bill.

props.synopsis: With so many technological advances, why does it feel like we spend more time doing paperwork than ever before? And who is profiting from all the virtual paper shuffling?

title.children: Businesses are now trying to sell everything 'as a service' and you're paying with your time

image.altText: A hand holding a $10 and $20 note of cash.

props.synopsis: The federal government announced a plan to change the way student debts were indexed months ago. Now the legislation will finally start saving students money.Â

title.children: HECS changes are finally law. It could mean student debt credits for some â and refunds for others

image.altText: Mining village in the foreground of a vast, shrub-based landscape, with red earth scattered between portable buildings.

props.synopsis: Efforts have been made to smooth tensions between junior miner Hastings Technology Metals and Andrew Forrest's Wyloo Metals over the financing of the Yangibana rare earths and niobium mine in WA.

title.children: Another $320m still needed to build rare earths mine in WA

image.altText: A young white toddler reads a book with her mother by a kitchen window

props.synopsis: The Inclusion Support Program aims to help early learning centres remove barriers that prevent them from including students with disability. But childcare workers have told the ABC they're having problems accessing the scheme.

title.children: 'Absolutely furious, bewildered, and sad': Families say multi-million-dollar 'inclusion' program is excluding their kids

image.altText: Jorja Spreadborough prepares for a cricket game with a helmet on and cricket batting cage in the background.

props.synopsis:
An outreach program is targeting Perth schools with higher rates of disadvantage by getting girls into cricket â and it's notching up runs both on and off the field.

Â 

Â

title.children: Program getting Perth schoolgirls on the cricket field about so much more than just the game

image.altText: Teen girl with curly hair and tan skin looks down at her phone wearing a stripy jumper. There are social media icons next to her

props.synopsis: Yesterday, parliament heard that the major parties will come together and pass a law banning teenagers from social media, after a period of careful thought roughly commensurate with that of a 15-year-old making a Black Friday impulse buy at Shein.com.

title.children: Parliament delivers a performance piece of legislative 'enshittification' that raises more questions than answers

image.altText: woman and man walking together being affectionate

props.synopsis: While sharing money is a not a prerequisite for a financially healthy relationship, experts say having a joint bank account has its benefits when managed the right way.

title.children: The pros and cons of opening a joint bank account

image.altText: A blurred photo of the share trading boards at the Australian stock exchange

props.synopsis: Australia's annual inflation rate remained steady in October at a more than three-year low as electricity and fuel prices fell. The local share market rose after a rally on Wall Street. Follow how the day's trade unfolded on the markets blog.

title.children: ASX rises as inflation rate stays steady, RBNZ cuts interest rates â as it happened

image.altText: Australian cricket coach Darren Lehmann, in a blue shirt, claps to honour remembrance of Phil Hughes on screen at Adelaide Oval.

props.synopsis: In 2014, Darren Lehmann answered the phone with news that would bear one of the most tragic moments in Australian sport. In a time when Australia is now searching for a Test opener, Phil Hughes should have been entering the twilight of his Test career. 10 years on from Hughes' death, it still hits home for many in the cricket world.

title.children: 'He would've just gone from strength to strength': Lehmann's emotional tribute to Hughes a decade on from his tragic death

image.altText: An oil slick on the ocean surface with a tanker in the background.

props.synopsis: Western Australia's industry watchdog alleges Santos did not operate its licensed pipeline in "a proper and workmanlike manner" to prevent the spill.

title.children: Regulator taking Santos to court after allegations 2022 oil spill killed dolphins, marine life

image.altText: A track cyclist wearing a British uniform looks to the stands with his finger raised in celebration after crossing the line.

props.synopsis: Matthew Richardson says AusCycling's lifetime ban on him is similar to an employer firing someone who has already resigned, but he says he hopes it will understand his defection to Team GB in time.

title.children: 'Just words on a piece of paper': Defector Richardson laughs off AusCycling life ban

image.altText: Ariel Bombara sits with her arms crossed.

props.synopsis: Ariel Bombara, the daughter of Floreat double murderer Mark Bombara, gives an extraordinary account of living under "persistent dread" from her abusive father, and denounces the heavy burden women carry for men's violence.

title.children: 'Do you believe me now?' Daughter of Floreat killer issues call to action at domestic violence rally
